metadata.case_name: State of Madras v. Purchaser of All India Trading Company

facts.text: Respondent purchased by registered instrument dated October 5, 1956, the business carried on by Purushottam Raju under the name All India Trading Company.
Purushottam Raju was sole proprietor and assessed to sales-tax for 1948-49 and 1949-50, paid some amounts but arrears remained: Rs. 3836-4-0 for 1948-49 and Rs. 1218-1-9 for 1949-50.
Sales-tax authorities attempted to recover arrears from respondent as purchaser under Rule 21-A.
Respondent denied liability; contention overruled by Deputy Commercial Tax Officer.
Respondent appealed to Commercial Tax Officer and Board of Revenue; appeals dismissed.
Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 for certiorari to quash orders of Commercial Tax Officer and Board of Revenue; dismissed by Ganapatia Pillai, J.
Respondent appealed under Letters Patent; Division Bench (S. Ramachandra Iyer, C.J. and Ramakrishnan, J.) reversed, holding Rule 21-A illegal and ultra vires; respondent not liable.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court from Madras High Court judgment dated September 13, 1963 in Writ Appeal No. 10 of 1962.
Madras General Sales-tax (3rd Amendment) Act, 1956 (Act No. XV of 1956) assented by President on October 1, 1956, published October 8, 1956; came into operation on publication date.
Amending Act of 1959 (Act 1 of 1959) inserted express provision making transferee liable for arrears, but not applicable to period concerned.

legal_issues.text: Whether the purchaser of business carried on by a dealer under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 can be made liable for arrears of sales-tax due from the dealer for transactions before transfer under Rule 21-A.
Whether Rule 21-A is intra vires the power of State Government under ss. 19(1) and 19(2)(c) of the Act.
Whether s. 10(1) of the Act charges the business property transferred with arrears, allowing recovery from transferee.
Whether the registered instrument dated October 5, 1956 creates liability on respondent towards State for arrears.

petitioner_arguments.text: State Government has power under s. 19(1) and 19(2)(c) to frame Rule 21-A.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 ss. 19(1), 19(2)(c)

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s. 10(1), amount outstanding on default is charge on properties of person liable; business transferred was charged, authorities can proceed against assets.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 s. 10(1); Madras General Sales-tax (3rd Amendment) Act, 1956

petitioner_arguments.text: Registered instrument dated October 5, 1956 shows respondent undertook to pay not only Sch. I liabilities but also sales-tax arrears.

respondent_arguments.text: No undertaking in registered instrument to discharge arrears of sales-tax.

court_reasoning.text: Purchaser as dealer assessed only on own turnover; pre-transfer sales turnover of transferor, not transferee; Rule 21-A creates fiction making transferee liable for transferor's turnover, beyond rule-making power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 3(1) charges dealer on own turnover; purchaser has nothing to do with seller's sales.

court_reasoning.text: s. 19(1) cannot enlarge scope to impose liability on non-dealer; s. 19(2)(c) on assessment of discontinued/changed ownership businesses does not include recovery from others; 'assessment' means computation, not recovery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Liability created by charging s.3; assessment is machinery.

court_reasoning.text: s. 10(1) charge on properties of 'person liable'; amendment effective Oct 8, 1956, post-transfer on Oct 5; old s.10 allowed recovery as land revenue arrears, not charge on business.
Even if respondent undertook to pay transferor, no privity with State; State cannot rely on private contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No contractual obligation between transferee and State.

holdings.text: Rule 21-A ultra vires rule-making power under s.19(1) or (2)(c); respondent not liable for predecessor's arrears.
s.10(1) amendment not applicable as transfer pre-dates operation.

precedents_cited.relevance: 'Assess' and 'assessment' refer primarily to computation of amount.
Liability to tax does not depend on assessment; created by charging sections.

precedents_cited.case_name: Whitney v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging on dealer's turnover; rule-making power limited; no liability on transferee for prior arrears.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales-tax (3rd Amendment) Act, 1956 (Act XV of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced charge on properties; operative from Oct 8, 1956.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax (Amending) Act, 1959 (Act 1 of 1959)
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted express transferee liability provision; post-period.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Clauses Act, 1891
statutes_cited.relevance: Acts come into operation on Gazette publication if not specified.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; judgment of Division Bench affirmed; Rule 21-A held ultra vires; respondent not liable for predecessor's sales-tax arrears.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ upheld; no liability on respondent.

key_quotes.text: Rule 21-A is beyond the rule-making power of the State Government either under s. 19(1) or s. 19(2)(c) of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on ultra vires nature.

key_quotes.text: the purchaser of the business has nothing to do with the sales effected by the seller of the business. The turnover in respect of such sales remains therefore the turnover of the transferor and not of the transferee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why transferee not liable under charging section.

key_quotes.text: It is not open to the State Government to rely on the instrument inter vivos between the transferor and the transferee and to contend that there is any contractual obligation between the transferee and the State Government who is not a party to the instrument.
key_quotes.speaker: court
